docs.lead_paragraph: CALL L. L. Bean, the clothing and outdoor gear company, don't identify yourself in any way, place your order, and see what happens. If you have shopped there before and you're calling from your home telephone number, the folks there know it -- even if you've blocked Caller ID. They know where you live. And they have your credit card number. In the course of the transaction, the cheerful sales clerk on the other end of the line will happily recite that information to you, letting you dispense with the tedium of giving your full credit card number or spelling your street name.

headline.main: Do You Know Who's Watching You? Do You Care?

docs.abstract: Privacy issues are raised by changes in technology that have made what used to be private information available to any company that will pay for it; thousands of computers linked to Web track individual patterns of online buying and behavior, which are translated in turn into highly sophisticated marketing strategies; most Americans are willing to part with personal information as long as they get something in return, and know what is to be done with information; but they are highly protective of their medical records and are generally appalled when they learn of clandestine data collection practices; photos (M)
docs.snippet: CALL L. L. Bean, the clothing and outdoor gear company, don't identify yourself in any way, place your order, and see what happens. If you have shopped there before and you're calling from your home telephone number, the folks there know it -- even...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ambivalence. Bill Bradley is being praised for proposing a bold new plan to make health insurance available to nearly all Americans, and for putting the health care issue back on the national agenda in a major way.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says plan by Democratic presidential candidate Bill Bradley to make health insurance available to nearly all Americans may be financially unrealistic and, in some ways could do more harm than good; examines Bradley's plan to do away with Medicaid, which has been 'like a safe house for the poor' (M)
docs.snippet: Ambivalence.    Bill Bradley is being praised for proposing a bold new plan to make health insurance available to nearly all Americans, and for putting the health care issue back on the national agenda in a major way.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional negotiators and Clinton administration officials announced tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on legislation to restore some of the money cut from Medicare in 1997. The cuts provoked howls of protest from the health care industry, which sent dozens of lobbyists to Capitol Hill to campaign for more money.

headline.main: Deal Is Struck On Restoring Medicare Aid

docs.abstract: Congressional negotiators and Clinton administration officials announce tentative agreement on legislation to restore some of money cut from Medicare in 1997 that provoked howls of protest from health care industry; deal will increase payments to most hospitals, nursing homes, health maintenance organizations and home health care agencies; will increase Medicare spending by $12 billion over next five years, or between 7 percent to 10 percent of amount cut by law in 1997; would gradually reduce huge disparities in what Medicare pays to train doctors in different parts of country; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congressional negotiators and Clinton administration officials announced tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on legislation to restore some of the money cut from Medicare in 1997.    The cuts provoked howls of protest from the health...

docs.lead_paragraph: Increase in Shares of U.P.S. Pushes Value to $81 Billion In the biggest initial stock offering ever, investors drove up the price of United Parcel Service to $68.25 a share from an opening price of $50. In less than 24 hours, the public increased the company's market value to more than $81 billion, almost twice as much as General Motors and nearly six times as much as Federal Express. Many of the company's shareholders are current or retired U.P.S. employees who are poised to cash in. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In a major shift in sales strategy, the Allstate Corporation said yesterday it would begin selling auto and homeowners' insurance and other coverage over the telephone and the Internet. The company, one of the nation's largest insurers, said it was not abandoning its force of 15,200 agents. But it expected them to continue selling and to provide service for customers who wanted personal attention after buying coverage through the new methods.

headline.main: Allstate Poised to Sell Insurance Over Telephone and Internet

docs.abstract: Allstate Corp, in major sales strategy, will begin selling auto and homeowners' insurance and other coverage over telephone and Internet; company says it is not abandoning its force of 15,200 agents, but it expects them to continue selling and to provide service for customers who want personal attention after buying coverage through new methods; company's trend toward converting its agents to independent contractors--who pay for office expenses and health insurance, instead of being Allstate employees--is accelerating; by July, there will be virtually no agents on staff; that will mean less job security for 6,500 agents who are still in process of changing to independent contractors; Allstate says it will cut 4,000 back-office positions, about 10 percent of its administrative staff, from its payroll by end of next year as part of plan to reduce operating expenses by $600 million annually (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was the featured speaker at a benefit dinner here tonight for The American Spectator magazine, whose 400 guests represented the nation's conservative establishment. Tables at the benefit, which was held in a ballroom of the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown, were purchased by such groups as the Heritage Foundation, the National Rifle Association and Forbes 2000 Inc. and a number of corporations.

headline.main: Giuliani Stresses Republican Ideals to Nation's Conservatives

docs.abstract: NYC Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, featured speaker at benefit dinner in Washington, DC, for American Spectator magazine, describes his potential Senate race against Hillary Rodham Clinton as golden opportunity to draw contrasts between Republican and Democratic political philosophies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As recently as a week ago, Dr. Elihu Sussman in New York would have an office assistant call a nurse at the UnitedHealth Group, one of the health maintenance organizations that he deals with, to request approval to send a patient for a magnetic imaging scan. The assistant would wait on the line, endure 20 minutes of elevator music, typically get the approval and send the patient on his or her way. Now the assistant will no longer have to listen to the music.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Shift May Please Patients, but Raise Costs

docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group's decision that would return decision-making power over patient care to physicians on issues like admitting health plan members to hospitals or providing other treatments may be popular with patients, but it is expected to raise costs slightly if number of procedures rise; as insurance companies respond to widespread complaints by partly relaxing their cost controls, overall health care costs are rising; large employers have already agreed to pay 8 percent to 10 percent more for health coverage next year, up from 7.8 percent increase this year; average cost per person would range from $3,947 for health maintenance organizations and $4,514 for discount networks of preferred providers to high of $6,285 for traditional unmanaged coverage; part of increase will be passed on to employees, who will pay about $110 more next year (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and MILT FREUDENHEIM

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group's decision to let doctors decide -- without the approval of the insurance company -- what care a patient should receive could signal a major change of course in the managed-care revolution. When the managed-care concept first burst upon the American health scene a decade or so ago it was touted as the best way to control runaway medical costs and to assure that all patients received the care they needed but not unnecessary care. As one key element of ''managing'' costs, insurance plan administrators were given the power to approve, in advance, any costly procedures and hospitalizations recommended by doctors participating in the plan. Whatever merit this approach had as a management tool, it was despised by both patients and doctors. But now, in a move that some describe as heralding a wave of change in the evolution of health care, United, one of the nation's largest managed-care companies, has said it will abandon the practice of questioning doctors' decisions before approving payment of medical bills.

headline.main: A Shift in the H.M.O. Revolution

docs.abstract: Editorial lauds decision by UnitedHealth Group, health maintenance organization, to let doctors decide without its approval what care patient should receive; says move could signal major change in course of managed-care revolution (M)
docs.snippet: The UnitedHealth Group's decision to let doctors decide -- without the approval of the insurance company -- what care a patient should receive could signal a major change of course in the managed-care revolution. When the managed-care concept first...

docs.lead_paragraph: Split along party lines, the Senate today approved a Republican plan to raise the federal minimum wage by $1 an hour over three years, to $6.15, and provide a variety of tax breaks mostly to the owners of small businesses. The Republican plan passed 54 to 44. Before that vote, the Senate rejected, 50 to 48, the Democratic alternative, a $1 hourly increase in the minimum wage over 13 months and more limited tax relief.

headline.main: $1 Increase in the Minimum Wage Wins Senate Approval but Faces a Clinton Veto

docs.abstract: Senate, split along party lines, approves by 54-44 vote plan to raise federal minimum wage by $1 per hour over three years, and to provide variety of tax breaks mostly to owners of small businesses; rejects Democratic alternative of $1 hourly increase over 13 months and limited tax relief; Pres Clinton accuses Republicans of using minimum-wage increase as cynical tool to advance special interest tax breaks; vows to veto legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When patients come to the University of Virginia Health System to have an abnormal heart rhythm diagnosed or treated, they are told that doctors will be threading thin wires through their veins directly into their heart. They learn that they run a slight risk of infection, or of damage to the heart, lungs or blood vessels from the very nature of the invasive procedure. But there is one thing they are not told: although the catheters and wires are labeled ''single use only,'' they may have been used before. They have been cleaned and sterilized, but they have spent time in someone else's blood vessels and heart.

headline.main: 'Single Use' Medical Devices Are Often Used Several Times

docs.abstract: Medical devices used for diagnostic and other tests are being reused more and more often in hospitals and clinics nationwide, despite 'single use only' labeling; experts say practice of reusing devices approved for only one-time use is not necessarily dangerous, but that it generally violates federal regulations; government, which has declined to ask companies that reprocess devices to submit evidence that they are safe and effective, is reconsidering approach because of pressure from manufacturers; some doctors and federal officials say issue is more about economics than safety, since manufacturers make less money when single-use devices are cleaned, sterilized and used again; hospitals and medical centers save money, in some cases tens of thousands of dollars annually, when devices are reused; are accused by manufacturers of putting patients at grave risk; Dr Larry Kessler, director at Food and Drug Administration, comments (M)
